title: What does a $100,000-a-night Las Vegas hotel suite look like? Look inside
text:
CLOSE

LAS VEGAS – Many people dream of earning $100,000 in a year.

On the 34th floor of The Palms, some blow $100,000 for one night here.

This 9,000-square-foot sky villa – called the “Empathy Suite” – is one of those rare luxury spots reserved for royalty and high rollers, reports the Reno Gazette Journal, which is part of the USA TODAY Network.

But many of the people staying here, a few blocks off the Strip on West Flamingo Road, don’t pay a dime – a complimentary stay given to celebrities or the “whales” with million-dollar casino credit lines.

“It’s Vegas,” said Jon Gray, who was general manager of the Palms Casino Resort until his resignation, announced Tuesday. “Your best suites go to your biggest players.”

Above the California king beds in the master bedroom are lifeless butterflies behind glass. (Photo: Ed Komenda / Reno Gazette-Journal)

A look inside The Palms Empathy Suite

Step off the elevators on the 34th floor of the Fantasy Tower, turn left and then right down two short hallways and you’ll find room 34201.

This is the “Empathy Suite.”

The 2.5 bathrooms each offer an imported Japanese automatic toilet seat with a motion detector that triggers the throne as you approach.

Anything you need: This Las Vegas butler delivered puppies for a high-dollar guest

The Empathy Suite has Japanese automatic toilet seats with a motion detectors. (Photo: Ed Komenda / Reno Gazette-Journal)

In both master bedrooms, every bed is a California king. The bathrooms, bigger than some one-bedroom apartments, have adjoining massage rooms.

There’s a gym, a “salt relaxation room,” a fully stocked bar and a pair of foosball and pool tables. On the balcony is a pool and Jacuzzi that overlooks the Strip.

In the room next door, there’s a butler. Always dressed in a suit, he's on call 24/7.

Who stays here?

Some celebrities. Some royalty from abroad.

But mostly the ones who inhabit this fantasy suite are the whales.

That’s what they call high-rollers in Vegas casinos. They’re the ones known to bet heavy – like $300,000 on a single hand of baccarat – and keep betting that way.

The pool of the Empathy Suite is only 2 feet, four inches deep – but a seat there offers one of the best views of Las Vegas. (Photo: Ed Komenda / Reno Gazette-Journal)

In return for their loyal play, these whales are given complimentary suites like the Empathy.

But not just anyone gets access. You must first qualify as a $1 million player and go through background and credit checks.

Those that choose to book the Empathy Suite – say a foreign dignitary who is also a fan of Damien Hirst’s art – must also go through a background check and put up a security deposit of $10,000 at check-in.

Vegas billionaire: Billionaire, friend get no-jail plea deal in Las Vegas drug case

“We’ve had some royalty come through,” Gray said. “Most of our guests have been international.”

Pianist-singer Alicia Keys stayed here with her husband. But that's only public because the pop star let her fans know on social media, Gray said.

Casino executives are very secretive about who stays at their high-roller celebrity suites.

The allure of expensive suite is the comfort of knowing your secrets never leave.

Why is it called the Empathy Suite?

This is "Winner/Loser" – a 2018 piece made with two bull sharks suspended in formaldehyde. (Photo: Ed Komenda / Reno Gazette-Journal)

Inside this 9,000-square-foot, two-floor villa, the first thing you see is a pair of bull sharks suspended in formaldehyde in a white tank set into the wall.

The sharp-toothed fish make up the parts of “Winner/Loser” – a piece by the artist who helped design the suite: Damien Hirst, an eccentric Englishman known for his use of dead creatures in his work.

Designed in collaboration with the architecture firm Bentel & Bentel, the Empathy Suite has Hirst’s personal touch all over it.

MGM Resorts: Hotel agrees to settlement up to $800 million for Vegas shooting victims

The furniture includes Hirst’s signature butterfly and pharmacy motifs – and two large-scale works of art – a large pill cabinet filled with diamonds and another filled with prescription pills.

The curved, glass bar is actually a case stuffed with 180 pounds of discarded medical items: rubber gloves, cotton-tipped applicators and even wooden tongue depressors.

Hirst named the functional bar-top art installation – wait for it – “Medical Waste.”

So what does any of this have to do with empathy?

Yes, those are real diamonds. (Photo: Ed Komenda / Reno Gazette-Journal)

In a statement, Hirst explained why he used the word to describe this peculiar Las Vegas “sky villa.”

"Empathy because I want you to feel empathy when you’re in it,” Hirst said, “empathy with all your friends wherever they are and whether you’re with them or not and to feel empathy when you’re spending the night with them in the suite and empathy with the whole world the morning after.”
